methodologies.note:
This module aims to cover the backgrounds of next generation sequencing (NGS). All lectures will be taught in English. 

Some lectures are focused around the theories behind a topic (how does genome assembly work?), whereas others focus around a question (why are we interested in this?). Strong emphasis are placed around evolutionary and ecological genomic topics in non-model organisms (i.e., non-human).

Target audiences are NTNU-TIGP students, NTU-GSB students who handed in work on time, or any postgraduate students who have sequencing data from non-model organisms but everyone in your lab including your PI have no idea about how to do with them. 

Depending on the number and ability of students I may tailor week12-16 to include more advanced practical or even let students to try real time sequencing using MinION.

grading.note:
Assignment; Students are expected hand in written assignments every two weeks as well as preparing a grant proposal. Failure to hand in written assignment late in two or more times will result in zero marks across entire assignment marks.
The grant proposal will be assessed by your own peers.
Final Exam; Multiple choice questions as well as short essays.
